reviewText:
Let me start this from scratch.

I've played Dragonica on gpotato back in time several years ago. I loved how unique the game was, and after the servers closed I didn't instantly forget about it, because it's one of the best MMO's I've ever played. I knew about its resurrection under the name of Dragon Saga, but it didn't really get me to play, until two days ago my cousin told me it's on steam. I instantly went on and installed it, because of previously stated reasons, and easy accessibility through steam. I thought it would be cool to play again. Boy, how wrong was I.

Let me make one thing clear; the game is still fantastic, and I still consider it one of the best MMO's ever. However, the current team that's working on it, is worse than having sex with a nuclear bomb. Its having literally every kind of issue an online game can have. It's VERY poorly optimized, localization is terrible (random japanese speaking NPC's, weirdly translated texts, unclear quest objects, and so on, the list is huge), servers are unstable (I still wasn't able to find out where they are located), you are lucky if you're even able to login. But even if you log in, you just cringe over the fact that it's buggy as hell, parts of maps randomly disappear, you lose your hp for no reason (please don't explain this again, I know why it's happening), and all that kind of stuff, that makes it a very unpleasant experience.

In conclusion, the game itself is pretty cool, and normally I'd recommend it to everyone, but in its current state it's literally unplayable. The team behind it should really do something about this mess, because now they only make themself look like some random group of people who know nothing about games in particular.

EDIT (please read this before you start complaining): Due to the high amount of views on my review, and to some of the nicer people clarifying some things to me, I've decided to edit my review. I'm NOT going to change it to recommended, because I still wouldn't recommend it to any player who wants a new MMO. But, I would totally recommend it to people, who've played Dragonica/Dragon Saga before, since it's KINDA the same thing, so you're most likely going to like it. My previously stated points still hold though, but as I've said in one of the comments here (which I advise you to read, or at least some of the decent ones) I have high hopes for this game to become succesful on steam, because it's insanely fun and I really hope the devs can make it a great experience to anyone. And most importantly, I hope that one day, I can recommend this game.

reviewText:
I've been playing this game since the 2009 release until the EU server closed down, moving to this last server. This was the mmo that I played for the longest time; it's incredibly fun (although frustrating sometimes), but the community always kept me playing. I feel like I've made some life long friends in this game.
The game went through a lot of changes; this server is the least pay-to-win-like, so far I didn't spend a cent on the game and levelled/geared up perfectly fine, which is a huge plus compared to the old EU server.
The combat system is fun too; the dungeons and grinding can become repetitive and boring though, especially after around lvl 40-50, when the only way to level up fast is to grind tactic mode.
There are events in the game regulalry, so there is usually always something to do besides the usual gold farming when you're already higher level.

To sum up the game:
Pros:
+ fun combat system
+ relatively fast levelling
+ not cash-shop heavy/pay2win
+ regular ingame events
+ awesome community
+ mods/staff are active on forums

Cons:
- grinding/questing can become repetitive
- many bugs
- translation errors/typos
- duping is still a thing
- occasional lags or crash-to-desktop (although I didn't have this for a long time now)
- can't log in to an already existing account through the Steam version (this is probably because of the achievements)

Overall, it is worth to try. It's not the best mmorpg out there, but there is definitely something about the game that makes people play it for such a long time.

The amount of side quests and storyline quests is insane, it makes the game really fun to play with friends, well even solo is fun as long as you find a good guild to hang out with. -When selecting a resolution and fullscreen mode right off the bat after starting the game for first time, it crashed for me (Steam only).

reviewText:
I have over 600 hours of game time on my main char on this server here, not even going to count the time I have on my other chars. I have played this game on the EU servers, IAH servers, Sea Servers and the good old THQ ice ones.
All of this sums up to about 6 years of gaming and about 40 different chars.

This might be just one more chibi style mmorpg some are saying. Let me tell you out of all the ones out there it is THE chibi style mmorpg.

This game comes with a really fun and fast combat system, amazing graphics and even the skill animations are just breath taking. We do have 3 sorts of pets, mounts, battle pets and just normal follow around ones (Yes even Dragons as pets - I know many like those).

The game comes with crafting system that is actually useful - the items you can craft do come without any real cash spending and believe it are not - are wanted, useful and do have a purpose.

reviewText:
This is NOT something you'll enjoy over time. I loved this game at first, but it quickly spiraled into disgust and hate.

Before trying this, I kept seeing mostly negative recommendations, without any explanation why. I really wish they'd mentioned exactly what was wrong with this. I've decided to actually add something to this.

And just so you know, I actually spent a good chunk of time on this--I have no idea why it didn't register. It also hasn't even listed any of the achievements I earned, and my character's over level 20.

For this I'm not going to look at the usual problems all mmo's have; this isn't exactly like every other mmo.

Pros:
>Combat system - It's an arcade-style mmorpg, so it's going to play as an arcade game at times. I actually really like this type of system because it doesn't rely on just chance to hit like the usual mmo.
>Customizable controls - You can map the controls out to whatever layout suits you best. This is pretty handy if you don't like/aren't used to using just the arrow keys to move
>Gamepad support - It's pretty awesome to be able to play this with a controller! I always look for that when I see games like this.

Meh:
>Window resolution - There aren't many options for how big you want the screen to be, and it can be a bother if you're playing on like, a laptop, but as long as you don't mess with the window too much, you won't have any problems.

And now, for the bad stuff.

Cons:
>NPC conversations - The dialogue for every character is so broken you can barely understand them. There are so many grammar and punctuation mistakes it's like kindergarteners were typing every bit of text. I don't need the phrasing to be perfect, I just need to understand the details of the quest, and this was impossible most of the time. I even constantly got lost since there were never any directions to the quest area.
>Adventure progression - I've been in the general area of the starting town literally since I started playing. It feels like the story takes forever to progress, just because some quests take you multiple times through the same dungeon. I'm not even at the second major town yet--it's taking that long. Add to that the weird, broken dialogue, and it'll make you feel like you're trapped in another, foreign world.
>Combat - I love the concept, but it needs more work. As soon as you hit a map with potential enemies, you're forcibly facing left or right, depending on which general direction has more of either. I didn't really mind it at first, but it got gradually harder and harder to line up attacks. There were a lot of times where I'd miss the target and leave myself wide open; it's sometimes impossible to not get hit immediately afterward. This even happened with bosses several times and almost got me killed.
>Enemy animation - This is as bad as the NPC dialogue, if not much worse. The enemy animation--usually for bosses--for attacking sometimes just halts, and this can catch you off guard. It's especially bad when you're facing a boss. This is the major reason I was having such a horrible time with the main dungeons. Pretty often when I knocked them over, I couldn't tell when they recovered from it, or that they even did, and they were suddenly immediately up and attacking without any indication that they were getting up.
>Dungeon rewards - I feel this is THE MOST broken part of the game. Whenever you complete a dungeon run, the rewards you obtain are determined by slot reels. However, when there's more than two, for some reason, you can only stop one reel, and the other two just continue spinning. I'd be okay with it, but the few times I managed to get more than two slots going, the loot the last two stopped on was ALWAYS THE SAME. Not to mention that the amount of rewards per grade isn't even balanced--I actually got more loot at around C or B than A or S, and the highest rank only gets you ONE GOD DAMN SLOT. Seriously, why has this NEVER been fixed??? It's so demoralizing to put so much work into perfectly maiming your enemies and hardly get anything out of it, or thinking you've scored more than one chance at loot and you can't keep it from ending up as the same thing you can't even use. On the subject of the grading system, it's practically impossible to get even a DECENT score without spamming attack skills, and like I said above, it's starting to get harder and harder to tell when an enemy is in contact range. Not to mention getting hit also reduces your score--I wouldn't have a problem with that if the random halting enemy animations didn't catch you by surprise.

It's a great concept, but this game is broken in more ways than one, and it just seems like there were more bugs than the team could even be bothered to fix. Everything about the dungeons, from the faulty animations to the buggy reward system, is unfair and unjustly frustrating; every bit of text--even the hints--was mostly lost in translation; and almost all the time you're going to get lost, because it's never clear what direction you have to go in.

In its current state, it's not even fit to be on Steam. To be honest, I doubt even Flowey would recommend this game.

Hopefully this will make more sense than all the blank, red No's on here. Hell, their reviews probably melted with their very brains trying to think of one way to save this buggy mess.

reviewText:
Despite my in game hours I've seen everything this game has to offer, you can trust me on that!

Dragon Saga is a very unique mmorpg in its activeness and the amount of control you have over your characters. If you enjoy very active hack and slash gameplay in a mmorpg setting, this game will provide you countless hours of just that.

The art style is very colourful and even childlike at places, but there are also vast dark sections like gloomy caves and fiery volcanic areas. The abilities are simple, yet combine to be very satisfying for both casual and more hardcore players. There are many classes, each with their own unique skill sets that give them all a different feel and look.

The community is very nice for the most part, the staff are active on social media and on the forums. So there's always someone to help. Support team responds quick enough and is polite, though sometimes the best help comes from the players themselves on the forum. The developers listen, take suggestions and engage in conversation with the players. We players have a lot of control over the direction the game goes in, and that's one very important thing.

The game has problems due to incompitent developers of the past. Pvp, while being very fun, is not supported by good game modes, ranked pvp or any sort of matchmaking. The group pvp modes have lots of problems. The economy is still recovering and shifting because of the vast history of abuse that has now ended. The translations are quite bad and the game doesn't explain it's self very well.

But those problems are slowly being fix and the future is, for the first time in a long long time, looking bright for this game.  Overall I recommend everyone to give this game a shot!

reviewText:
I have played this game for about 20 hours as I type this in a matter of 2 days of owning it, and I still can't fully decide if I actually like it or not.

Pros:
If you're a perfectionist for achievments, there's sooooo many and im only level 30.
Game play for the most part is smooth. Loads very quickly and few general bugs.
Very friendly players from my experience. (Though, a lot of people will tend to steal your kills)
Marriage and couple perks. (I dunno, I thought it was cute.)
Animation and designs are pretty cute looking.


Cons:
Steam has a hard time syncing achievments with its system.
Most main boss missions must be cleared 5+ times. This isn't because of a bug, that's just how quests work.
Combat is a 3-D side scroller, meaning aiming and positioning can be hard depending on which class you pick.
Very basic classes, until you reach lvl 20 on a human character to unlock the 'Dragonkin' race.
Dragonkin only has 2 classes to pick from (Shaman and Twins)
Character customization is BEYOND basic. You can choose between maybe 7 hair styles and like 5 facial expressions (unable to change eye colour)
Can be VERY buggy at times during combat, tends to lag on occasions.
Broken English, which has even made some quests misleading. (IE 'Dropped from Ember Wolves' when it's actually dropped from Brown Wolves)
Long walks from area to area if you don't want to use your money to fast travel.
Can get very tedious if you follow side quests (Which I enjoy personally)
Lore in my opinion is very boring. I watched the starting movie, skip all dialouge, and skim quests (just so I know what to do).

While there are more cons than there are pros, I will recommend this game to others as it can be pretty fun. And maybe soon I'll finally figure out if I actually like it or not myself.

reviewText:
Despite my in game hours I've seen everything this game has to offer, you can trust me on that!

Dragon Saga is a very unique mmorpg in its activeness and the amount of control you have over your characters. If you enjoy very active hack and slash gameplay in a mmorpg setting, this game will provide you countless hours of just that.

The art style is very colourful and even childlike at places, but there are also vast dark sections like gloomy caves and fiery volcanic areas. The abilities are simple, yet combine to be very satisfying for both casual and more hardcore players. There are many classes, each with their own unique skill sets that give them all a different feel and look.

The community is very nice for the most part, the staff are active on social media and on the forums. So there's always someone to help. Support team responds quick enough and is polite, though sometimes the best help comes from the players themselves on the forum. The developers listen, take suggestions and engage in conversation with the players. We players have a lot of control over the direction the game goes in, and that's one very important thing.

The game has problems due to incompitent developers of the past. Pvp, while being very fun, is not supported by good game modes, ranked pvp or any sort of matchmaking. The group pvp modes have lots of problems. The economy is still recovering and shifting because of the vast history of abuse that has now ended. The translations are quite bad and the game doesn't explain it's self very well.

But those problems are slowly being fix and the future is, for the first time in a long long time, looking bright for this game.  Overall I recommend everyone to give this game a shot!
